    Highlights

    •
    Mitochondria-located circRNA SCAR inhibits mROS output and fibroblast activation
    •
    circRNA SCAR shuts down mPTP by binding to ATP5B
    •
    Lipid-induced ER stress impairs PGC-1α-mediated circRNA SCAR expression
    •
    Mitochondria-specific delivery of circRNA SCAR alleviates metaflammation in vivo

    Summary

    Mitochondria, which play central roles in immunometabolic diseases, have their own genome. However, the functions of mitochondria-located noncoding RNAs are largely unknown due to the absence of a specific delivery system. By circular RNA (circRNA) expression profile analysis of liver fibroblasts from patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), we observe that mitochondrial circRNAs account for a considerable fraction of downregulated circRNAs in NASH fibroblasts. By constructing mitochondria-targeting nanoparticles, we observe that Steatohepatitis-associated circRNA ATP5B Regulator (SCAR), which is located in mitochondria, inhibits mitochondrial ROS (mROS) output and fibroblast activation. circRNA SCAR, mediated by PGC-1α, binds to ATP5B and shuts down mPTP by blocking CypD-mPTP interaction. Lipid overload inhibits PGC-1α by endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress-induced CHOP. In vivo, targeting circRNA SCAR alleviates high fat diet-induced cirrhosis and insulin resistance. Clinically, circRNA SCAR is associated with steatosis-to-NASH progression. Collectively, we identify a mitochondrial circRNA that drives metaflammation and serves as a therapeutic target for NASH.

    Results

    mROS Is Required for the Pro-inflammatory Phenotype of Lipid-Exposed Fibroblasts

    Fibroblasts orchestrate fibrosis in multiple diseases. Among them, NAFLD affects 25% of the global population (Younossi et al., 2018
    89.
    Younossi, Z. ∙ Anstee, Q.M. ∙ Marietti, M. ...
    Global burden of NAFLD and NASH: trends, predictions, risk factors and prevention
    Nat. Rev. Gastroenterol. Hepatol. 2018; 15:11-20
    Crossref
    Scopus (3399)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To investigate the mitochondrial metabolism of fibroblasts in NAFLD patients, we isolated fibroblasts from liver tissues of patients with NASH cirrhosis and those without NAFLD (Su et al., 2018
    77.
    Su, S. ∙ Chen, J. ∙ Yao, H. ...
    CD10(+)GPR77(+) Cancer-Associated Fibroblasts Promote Cancer Formation and Chemoresistance by Sustaining Cancer Stemness
    Cell. 2018; 172:841-856
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (802)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Su et al., 2015
    76.
    Su, S. ∙ Zhao, Q. ∙ He, C. ...
    miR-142-5p and miR-130a-3p are regulated by IL-4 and IL-13 and control profibrogenic macrophage program
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:8523
    Crossref
    Scopus (191)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Using Seahorse extracellular flux analyzer, we observed that both extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) and oxygen consumption rate (OCR) increased in NASH fibroblasts compared with normal fibroblasts (Figure 1A). However, the ECAR/OCR ratio was significantly elevated in NASH fibroblasts (Figure 1B). Consistently, the ECAR/OCR ratio was greatly enhanced in normal fibroblasts treated with palmitate (Figure 1C), which recapitulates lipid exposure in vitro (Machado et al., 2015
    54.
    Machado, M.V. ∙ Michelotti, G.A. ∙ Pereira, Tde.A. ...
    Reduced lipoapoptosis, hedgehog pathway activation and fibrosis in caspase-2 deficient mice with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
    Gut. 2015; 64:1148-1157
    Crossref
    Scopus (71)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Of note, palmitate treatment slightly increased the apoptosis of fibroblasts (Figure S1A). Together, these data suggested that ATP production in fibroblasts switches from mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation to glycolysis under lipid burden.
    Mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) generated by proton pumps of the electron transport chain is required for ATP production. Therefore, we evaluated ΔΨm by JC-1 fluorescence and found that ΔΨm in NASH fibroblasts was markedly lower (Figures 1D and 1E). Electronic microscopy demonstrated that the ΔΨm suppression was accompanied by the swelling of the mitochondria (Figure 1F), indicating mitochondrial stress. ROS often increases in mitochondrial stress (Shadel and Horvath, 2015
    74.
    Shadel, G.S. ∙ Horvath, T.L.
    Mitochondrial ROS signaling in organismal homeostasis
    Cell. 2015; 163:560-569
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (865)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Thus, we evaluated both mROS and cytosolic ROS (cROS) using two approaches, including fluorescent dyes MitoSOX and DCFH-DA (West et al., 2011
    82.
    West, A.P. ∙ Brodsky, I.E. ∙ Rahner, C. ...
    TLR signalling augments macrophage bactericidal activity through mitochondrial ROS
    Nature. 2011; 472:476-480
    Crossref
    Scopus (1219)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), and transduction with compartment-specific ROS sensors mitoORP and cytoORP, respectively (Dey et al., 2018
    15.
    Dey, S. ∙ DeMazumder, D. ∙ Sidor, A. ...
    Mitochondrial ROS Drive Sudden Cardiac Death and Chronic Proteome Remodeling in Heart Failure
    Circ. Res. 2018; 123:356-371
    Crossref
    Scopus (175)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In parallel to ΔΨm suppression, both mROS and cROS significantly increased in NASH fibroblasts (Figures 1G–1J). Similarly, palmitate exposure markedly increased mROS and cROS levels (Figures S1B and S1C). mROS can be released into the cytosol via mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP), which is an important source of cROS (Dey et al., 2018
    15.
    Dey, S. ∙ DeMazumder, D. ∙ Sidor, A. ...
    Mitochondrial ROS Drive Sudden Cardiac Death and Chronic Proteome Remodeling in Heart Failure
    Circ. Res. 2018; 123:356-371
    Crossref
    Scopus (175)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Kwong and Molkentin, 2015
    43.
    Kwong, J.Q. ∙ Molkentin, J.D.
    Physiological and pathological roles of the mitochondrial permeability transition pore in the heart
    Cell Metab. 2015; 21:206-214
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (324)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Consistently, administration of mPTP inhibitors (cyclosporine A) significantly reduced cROS levels in both NASH fibroblasts and normal fibroblasts treated with palmitate (Figures S1D and S1E). These data suggested that fibroblasts with lipid exposure exhibit mitochondrial stress with elevated mROS production and efflux into cytosol.
    Although ROS is required for optimal activation of multiple immune cells (Mills et al., 2017
    60.
    Mills, E.L. ∙ Kelly, B. ∙ O’Neill, L.A.J.
    Mitochondria are the powerhouses of immunity
    Nat. Immunol. 2017; 18:488-498
    Crossref
    Scopus (655)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Sena et al., 2013
    73.
    Sena, L.A. ∙ Li, S. ∙ Jairaman, A. ...
    Mitochondria are required for antigen-specific T cell activation through reactive oxygen species signaling

    ), whether ROS mediates fibroblast activation remains unclear. To address this, we treated primary NASH fibroblasts with ROS inhibitors and observed that the contractility (Figure 1K), collagen synthesis, and α-SMA expression (Figure 1L) were abrogated. Moreover, ROS inhibition attenuated the secretion of inflammatory cytokines (Figure 1M). Again, ROS blockade abolished the pro-fibrotic and pro-inflammatory functions of palmitate-treated fibroblasts (Figures S1F and S1G). Collectively, these results suggested that lipid accumulation increases mROS output, which promotes fibroblast activation.

    Lipid Exposure Induces Mitochondrial circRNomics Imbalance in Fibroblasts

    circRNAs are key signaling regulators in multiple cell types (Li et al., 2018
    47.
    Li, X. ∙ Yang, L. ∙ Chen, L.L.

    ). However, the roles of circRNAs in fibroblasts are elusive. Thus, we compared the circRNA expression profiles between primary fibroblasts isolated from 4 patients with NASH cirrhosis and 4 patients without NAFLD. 15 and 11 circRNAs were consistently upregulated and downregulated respectively in NASH fibroblasts (Figures 2A and S2A–S2C). Strikingly, a large fraction of (4 out of 11) downregulated circRNAs were encoded by the mitochondrial genome (Figure 2B), despite nuclear circRNAs accounting for an overwhelming majority of the whole circRNomics (Figure S2D) (Jeck et al., 2013
    35.
    Jeck, W.R. ∙ Sorrentino, J.A. ∙ Wang, K. ...

Among them, the suppression of 3 mitochondrial circRNAs (mito-circRNAs) in NASH patients was validated by qRT-PCR in another cohort consisting of 18 patients with NASH cirrhosis and 20 patients without NAFLD (Figure 2C). The fractionation experiment demonstrated that these circRNAs were mainly located in the mitochondria rather than the cytosol (Figure 2D). Divergent PCR followed by sequencing analysis demonstrated that these 3 mito-circRNAs are all generated from the mitochondrial genome through “backsplices” mechanism (Figure S2E). The mature transcripts all contain exonic sequences despite hsa_circ_0089763 having an intron retained between exons. Among them, hsa_circ_0089762 and hsa_circ_0089763 are generated from the light strand of mito-DNA, while hsa_circ_0008882 is generated from the heavy strand (Figure 2E).
    To investigate these mito-circRNAs, we constructed a mitochondria-targeting nanoparticle (mito-NP) platform.     ). Thus, we could not construct hsa_circ_0089763 mito-NP. Together, these data suggested that the suppression of mito-circRNAs may play a role in the activation of NASH fibroblasts.

    circRNA SCAR Is Located in Mitochondria and Inhibits Fibroblast Activation

    Next, we further explored the role of circRNA SCAR in fibroblast activation. Using a specific probe to detect the circular rather than known linear transcript of SCAR in circBase (Figure 3A), RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and co-immunofluorescence staining demonstrated that 90.38% ± 2.56% of endogenous circRNA SCAR signals co-localized within the mitochondria (Figure 3B). Using primers that specifically detected the circular and linear transcripts of SCAR, respectively (Figure 3C), we performed absolute qRT-PCR. Our data showed that circRNA SCAR was 966.37 ± 114.68 copies per normal fibroblast, which was significantly higher than its linear version (443.27 ± 43.69) (Figures 3D and S3A). Both circular and linear SCAR dramatically decreased in NASH fibroblasts (Figure 3D). The ratio of circular to linear SCAR further increased in NASH fibroblasts (Figure S3B). We confirmed that circRNA SCAR was circRNA by RNase R digestion analysis (Figure 3D).
    circRNA SCAR originates from the circularization of the second exon of its host gene (JA760602) (Figure 2E). We inserted exon 2 into a circRNA overexpression vector (Figure 3C) (Han et al., 2017
    28.
    Han, D. ∙ Li, J. ∙ Wang, H. ...
    Circular RNA circMTO1 acts as the sponge of microRNA-9 to suppress hepatocellular carcinoma progression
    Hepatology. 2017; 66:1151-1164
    Crossref
    Scopus (946)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and encapsulated it in mito-NP. Incubation of circRNA SCAR mito-NP significantly increased circRNA SCAR (Figure 3E) but had no appreciable effect on its unspliced precursor or linear transcript (Figure S3C). The levels of circRNA SCAR in the mitochondrial fraction, which was resistant to RNase R, was much higher than those in the cytosolic fraction (Figure 3E). Furthermore, Northern blot analysis demonstrated that circRNA SCAR mito-NP treatments significantly increased circRNA SCAR that was resistant to RNase R. By contrast, its linear transcript, which was susceptible to RNase R, remained unchanged (Figure 3F). Moreover, sequencing of the vector’s RNA product showed a perfect match to the endogenous circRNA SCAR (Figure S3D).
    Functionally, mitochondria-specific overexpression of circRNA SCAR significantly reduced both mROS and cROS levels (Figure S3E) and reversed the depression of ΔΨm in NASH fibroblasts (Figure 3G). We found no appreciable effect on the ECAR/OCR ratio (Figure S3F). These data suggested that circRNA SCAR in mitochondria inhibits ROS generation and ΔΨm suppression.
    Given that lipid burden leads to mROS accumulation, we asked whether circRNA SCAR can be regulated by lipid treatments. Indeed, we observed that palmitate dramatically decreased circRNA SCAR expression (Figure 3H). More importantly, incubation of circRNA SCAR mito-NP abrogated the elevation of mROS and cROS (Figure 3I) and ΔΨm reduction (Figure 3J) induced by palmitate, indicating that circRNA SCAR suppressed by lipid regulates ROS release and ΔΨm in the mitochondria.
    In consistence with the overexpression experiments, circRNA SCAR knockdown in palmitate-treated fibroblasts further increased mROS and reduced ΔΨm (Figures S3G–S3I). However, silencing circRNA SCAR in normal fibroblasts had no appreciable effect (Figures S3G, S3J, and S3K), suggesting that the suppression of circRNA SCAR alone in normal fibroblasts does not significantly change ROS or ΔΨm.
    Next, we asked whether circRNA SCAR also regulates pro-fibrotic functions of fibroblasts. circRNA SCAR overexpression substantially attenuated the expression of collagen and α-SMA (Figure 3K), collagen contraction, (Figure 3L) and cytokine secretion (Figure 3M) in NASH fibroblasts. Similarly, circRNA SCAR overexpression also inhibited the activation of palmitate-treated fibroblasts (Figures S3L and S3M). Additionally, silencing circRNA SCAR in palmitate-treated fibroblasts further enhanced their pro-fibrotic phenotypes (Figures S3N and S3O). Together, these data indicated that mito-circRNA SCAR suppressed by lipid burden inhibits ROS elevation and activation of fibroblasts.

    circRNA SCAR Directly Binds to ATP5B

    Next, we investigated the mechanism of circRNA SCAR. Although a potential open reading frame (ORF) was predicted in circRNA SCAR, we inserted a 3× FLAG-coding sequence upstream of the stop codon in the potential ORF sequence and detected no flagged protein (Figure S4A), suggesting that circRNA SCAR is a noncoding RNA. Moreover, we identified putative binding sites for several microRNAs in circRNA SCAR (Figure S4B). However, none of these microRNAs contain more than two binding sites or are transcribed by the mitochondrial genome, suggesting that circRNA SCAR does not serve as microRNA sponges (Hansen et al., 2013

    The downregulation of circRNA SCAR by lipid prompted us to explore its expression mechanism. Bioinformative analysis identified a putative PGC-1α consensus site located at −25 to −18 bp of light strand promoter, which is responsible for circRNA SCAR transcription in the mitochondrial genome (Figure 6F). Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) revealed that anti-PGC-1α antibody precipitated this motif (Figure 6G). In agreement with circRNA SCAR expression, palmitate significantly diminished PGC-1α (Figure 6H) and its' binding to the putative motif in the mitochondria (Figure 6G). Moreover, silencing endogenous PGC-1α markedly reduced circRNA SCAR expression (Figures 6I and S6C), indicating that PGC-1α regulates circRNA SCAR transcription.

    circRNA SCAR Alleviates High Fat Diet-Induced Cirrhosis in Mice

    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Indeed, human circRNA SCAR could bind to mouse ATP5B (Figure S7A). Overexpression of circRNA SCAR inhibited mPTP opening (Figure S7B), cROS release (Figure S7C), and collagen contraction (Figure S7D) in mouse fibroblasts.
    To evaluate whether mito-NP can be efficiently delivered into the mitochondria of liver fibroblasts in vivo, we labeled the circRNA expression vectors with Cy5 fluorescence. Naked vectors or vectors encapsulated by mito-NP were injected via tail vein into mice. mito-NP exhibited higher fluorescence signals than naked vectors in major organs. Among them, the livers showed the highest mito-NP accumulation (Figures 7A and S7E). To investigate the cellular percentage of mito-NP uptake, we isolated fibroblasts from livers. 20.32% ± 3.67% and 74.12% ± 7.05% fibroblasts were Cy5+ after injection of naked vectors and mito-NP, respectively (Figures 7B and S7F). To quantitate the mito-NP accumulation in the mitochondria, we performed the organelle fractionation and observed a more than 10-fold enrichment of mito-NP in the mitochondria compared with the cytosol (Figures 7C and S7G).
    To investigate the therapeutic potential of circRNA SCAR in vivo, we intravenously administered mito-NP containing circRNA SCAR overexpression vectors or empty vectors every 3 days to the mice fed with high fat-diet. We did not observe obvious toxicity in mice treated with mito-NP (Table S2). FISH and co-immunofluorescence staining showed that 86.07% ± 7.17% circRNA SCAR signals co-localized with the mitochondria in the mice administered with circRNA SCAR mito-NP (Figures 7D and S7H). Organelle fractionation assays of isolated fibroblasts showed that circRNA SCAR in the mitochondrial fraction was 14.92 ± 1.79-fold more than that in the cytosol (Figure 7E). We did not detect its linear version by overexpressing circRNA SCAR in vivo (Figure 7E).
    The increased levels of circRNA SCAR in the mitochondria of liver fibroblasts were accompanied by inhibition of ROS levels (Figure S7I) and cytokine expression (Figure S7J). More importantly, the treatment of circRNA SCAR mito-NP substantially improved tolerance of glucose (Figure S7K) and insulin (Figure 7F), halted weight gain (Figure S7L), and reduced fibrosis and macrophage infiltration of livers (Figure 7G) in mice fed with high fat-diet.

    circRNA SCAR Correlates with Steatosis-to-NASH Progression in Patients

    To investigate the clinical significance of circRNA SCAR, we evaluated its expression in liver tissues of patients with or without NAFLD by FISH. circRNA SCAR was located in the mitochondria and was predominantly detected in fibroblasts (Figure 7H). More importantly, circRNA SCAR expression was significantly reduced in NAFLD patients compared with those without NAFLD and exhibited a continuous decline from simple steatosis to NASH cirrhosis (Figures 7I and S7M). Furthermore, circRNA SCAR expression in fibroblasts was negatively correlated with both the cROS level and severity of fibrosis (Figures 7I and 7J) in liver samples of NAFLD patients. Additionally, homeostasis model assessment-insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), an insulin resistance score, was inversely correlated with circRNA SCAR+ liver fibroblast percentage (Figure S7N). Collectively, these results indicated that circRNA SCAR downregulation in liver fibroblasts is closely associated with steatosis-to-NASH progression and insulin resistance in patients.

    Discussion

    Liver, the central hub for bodily lipid metabolism, is the most highly exposed organ to lipotoxicity. Metaflammation is a chronic inflammation driven by nutrient excess (Franceschi et al., 2018
    19.
    Franceschi, C. ∙ Garagnani, P. ∙ Parini, P. ...
    Inflammaging: a new immune-metabolic viewpoint for age-related diseases
    Nat. Rev. Endocrinol. 2018; 14:576-590
    Crossref
    Scopus (1525)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Hotamisligil, 2017
    32.
    Hotamisligil, G.S.
    Inflammation, metaflammation and immunometabolic disorders
    Nature. 2017; 542:177-185
    Crossref
    Scopus (1419)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). It lies at the center of immunometabolic diseases. Thus, understanding the underlying mechanisms of metaflammation is of paramount importance to develop treatments for metabolic diseases. Here, we uncovered the detailed molecular components of an ER-nucleus-mitochondria-cytosol communication pathway that drives lipid-mediated inflammation (Figure S7O). To our knowledge, this is the first report to highlight the biological significance of mitochondria-located circRNAs. More importantly, we demonstrated targeting mito-circRNAs can be a specific and restricted therapeutic strategy for immunometabolic disorders.
    Our circRNomics analysis of primary liver fibroblasts from patients allowed us to perform a global assessment of the dynamic circRNA profiles during NASH. To our surprise, circRNAs transcribed by the mitochondrial genome accounted for nearly 40% of the downregulated circRNAs in NASH fibroblasts, despite they are less than 0.1% of the overall circRNomics. This sharp contrast strongly indicated that metabolic insults have significant impacts on the mitochondrial circRNomics in fibroblasts.
    Although it has been reported that the binding of CypD to ATP synthase in mPTP complex is crucial for mPTP opening (Antoniel et al., 2018
    2.
    Antoniel, M. ∙ Jones, K. ∙ Antonucci, S. ...
    The unique histidine in OSCP subunit of F-ATP synthase mediates inhibition of the permeability transition pore by acidic pH
    EMBO Rep. 2018; 19:257-268
    Crossref
    Scopus (87)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Giorgio et al., 2013
    22.
    Giorgio, V. ∙ von Stockum, S. ∙ Antoniel, M. ...
    Dimers of mitochondrial ATP synthase form the permeability transition pore
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2013; 110:5887-5892
    Crossref
    Scopus (751)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), its regulatory mechanisms are largely unknown. We found that circRNA SCAR directly binds to ATP5B of ATP synthase in mPTP complex and blocks the interaction between CypD and mPTP during the resting state. Lipid-induced ER stress reduces PGC-1α-mediated circRNA SCAR expression by CHOP, relieves the inhibition on CypD-mPTP binding and facilitates mPTP opening. Interestingly, the linear transcript of SCAR is a mitochondrial long noncoding RNA, which is dysregulated in patients with chronic heart failure (Kumarswamy et al., 2014
    42.
    Kumarswamy, R. ∙ Bauters, C. ∙ Volkmann, I. ...
    Circulating long noncoding RNA, LIPCAR, predicts survival in patients with heart failure
    Circ. Res. 2014; 114:1569-1575
    Crossref
    Scopus (521)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), another disease closely associated with mitochondrial dysfunction (Okonko and Shah, 2015
    63.
    Okonko, D.O. ∙ Shah, A.M.
    Heart failure: mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress in CHF
    Nat. Rev. Cardiol. 2015; 12:6-8
    Crossref
    Scopus (76)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Whether its cognate linear RNA participates in the mechanisms of circRNA SCAR warrants further studies.
    Despite its detrimental effects, accumulating evidences have indicated that mROS is essential to maintain body homeostasis and extend lifespan. The difficulty to untangle its double-edge sword effects poses a huge dilemma for mROS-targeting therapy (Rottenberg and Hoek, 2017
    70.
    Rottenberg, H. ∙ Hoek, J.B.
    The path from mitochondrial ROS to aging runs through the mitochondrial permeability transition pore
    Aging Cell. 2017; 16:943-955
    Crossref
    Scopus (176)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Shadel and Horvath, 2015
    74.
    Shadel, G.S. ∙ Horvath, T.L.
    Mitochondrial ROS signaling in organismal homeostasis
    Cell. 2015; 163:560-569
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (865)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Our results suggested that this challenge can be circumvented by targeting mito-circRNA SCAR. First, manipulating circRNA SCAR expression had no appreciable effect on mROS levels in resting fibroblasts, suggesting circRNA SCAR alone is not sufficient to initiate changes of mROS, but finely tunes mROS levels during excessive mPTP opening. Second, this conclusion is further supported that no obvious toxicity could be observed in mice treated with mito-NP containing circRNA SCAR. Third, it has been postulated that circRNAs are resistant to most RNA degrading machineries due to their circular structures and therefore very stable in vivo (Chen, 2016
    8.
    Chen, L.L.
    The biogenesis and emerging roles of circular RNAs
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2016; 17:205-211
    Crossref
    Scopus (1274)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Lasda and Parker, 2014
    45.
    Lasda, E. ∙ Parker, R.
    Circular RNAs: diversity of form and function
    RNA. 2014; 20:1829-1842
    Crossref
    Scopus (965)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Our study provided proof-of-concept evidences by showing that intravenous injection of mito-NP containing circRNA SCAR significantly increased its levels in mouse livers and mitigated high fat diet-induced cirrhosis.
    The generation of nuclear circRNAs is tightly controlled by pre-mRNA splicing machinery (Ebbesen et al., 2017
    18.
    Ebbesen, K.K. ∙ Hansen, T.B. ∙ Kjems, J.
    Insights into circular RNA biology
    RNA Biol. 2017; 14:1035-1045
    Crossref
    Scopus (354)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Kristensen et al., 2019
    41.
    Kristensen, L.S. ∙ Andersen, M.S. ∙ Stagsted, L.V.W. ...
    The biogenesis, biology and characterization of circular RNAs
    Nat. Rev. Genet. 2019; 20:675-691
    Crossref
    Scopus (2816)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Wilusz, 2017
    83.
    Wilusz, J.E.
    Circular RNAs: Unexpected outputs of many protein-coding genes
    RNA Biol. 2017; 14:1007-1017

    Scopus (92)

    , 2018

    Wiley Interdiscip. Rev. RNA. 2018; 9:e1478
    Crossref
    Scopus (361)

    ). Many splicing factors regulate the biogenesis of nuclear circRNAs by mediating alternative splicing events (Ashwal-Fluss et al., 2014
    3.
    Ashwal-Fluss, R. ∙ Meyer, M. ∙ Pamudurti, N.R. ...
    circRNA biogenesis competes with pre-mRNA splicing
    Mol. Cell. 2014; 56:55-66
    Full Text

    Scopus (2333)

    ; Kramer et al., 2015

    Kramer, M.C. ∙ Liang, D. ∙ Tatomer, D.C. ...
    Combinatorial control of Drosophila circular RNA expression by intronic repeats, hnRNPs, and SR proteins
    Genes Dev. 2015; 29:2168-2182
    Crossref
    Scopus (371)
    PubMed

    ; Liang et al., 2017
    49.
    Liang, D. ∙ Tatomer, D.C. ∙ Luo, Z. ...
    The Output of Protein-Coding Genes Shifts to Circular RNAs When the Pre-mRNA Processing Machinery Is Limiting
    Mol. Cell. 2017; 68:940-954
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (301)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). All the proteins encoded by the mitochondrial genome are components of the oxidative phosphorylation system. The protein factors that regulate mitochondrial RNA metabolism are entirely encoded by the nucleus and imported from the cytoplasm (Nicholls et al., 2013
    62.
    Nicholls, T.J. ∙ Rorbach, J. ∙ Minczuk, M.
    Mitochondria: mitochondrial RNA metabolism and human disease
    Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2013; 45:845-849

    ). Consistent with this notion, our data showed that hnRNPM, a component of nuclei-encoded spliceosome mediating mitochondrial RNA processing (Herai et al., 2017
    31.
    Herai, R.H. ∙ Negraes, P.D. ∙ Muotri, A.R.
    Evidence of nuclei-encoded spliceosome mediating splicing of mitochondrial RNA

    ), is involved in circRNA SCAR biogenesis. These data suggested that, similar to their nuclear counterparts, mito-circRNAs are not merely transcriptional noise, but precisely regulated.
    In summary, we showed that targeting a disrupted inter-organelle metabolic axis by interfering mito-circRNAs provides an attractive therapeutic strategy for immunometabolic diseases.

    Experimental Model and Subject Details

    NAFLD Patients and Liver Samples

    Liver biopsies of adult NAFLD patients with simple steatosis (n = 33), NASH with no or mild fibrosis (n = 29) or NASH-cirrhosis (n = 15) were collected from the Third Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University. The surgically resected liver samples of adult NAFLD patients who received hepatic hemangioma or liver transplant operation with simple steatosis (n = 13), NASH with no or mild fibrosis (n = 18), or NASH-cirrhosis (n = 18), were collected from the Third Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University and the First Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University. Other etiologies of liver disease, including viral, autoimmune, cholestatic, genetic, alcoholic, and drug-induced were excluded. In addition, normal liver tissues were obtained from 51 patients undergoing surgery for hepatic hemangioma in the Third Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University. The mean age of the patients was 43 years old. 112 patients were male and 65 were female.
    Liver histology was assessed separately by two liver pathologists without knowledge of the clinical data following the 2018 Practice Guidance from the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases (Chalasani et al., 2018
    7.
    Chalasani, N. ∙ Younossi, Z. ∙ Lavine, J.E. ...
    The diagnosis and management of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease: Practice guidance from the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases
    Hepatology. 2018; 67:328-357
    Crossref
    Scopus (4589)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The NAFLD patients were defined as the presence of ≥ 5% hepatic steatosis without evidence of hepatocellular injury in the form of hepatocyte ballooning. NASH is defined as the presence of ≥ 5% hepatic steatosis and inflammation with hepatocyte injury (e.g., ballooning), with or without any fibrosis. Liver fibrosis was staged on a 0 to 4 scale according to the METAVIR scoring system: F0, no fibrosis; F1, portal fibrosis without septa; F2, portal fibrosis and few septa; F3, numerous septa without cirrhosis; F4, cirrhosis. All samples were anonymously coded in accordance with local ethical guidelines (as stipulated by the Declaration of Helsinki), and written informed consent was obtained. The protocol was approved by the Review Board of the Third Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-Sen University and the First Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-Sen University.

    Primary Liver Fibroblasts

    Primary human and mouse liver fibroblasts were isolated from liver biopsy or surgically resected samples from patients and mouse livers as we and others previously described (Mederacke et al., 2015
    56.
    Mederacke, I. ∙ Dapito, D.H. ∙ Affò, S. ...
    High-yield and high-purity isolation of hepatic stellate cells from normal and fibrotic mouse livers
    Nat. Protoc. 2015; 10:305-315
    Crossref
    Scopus (374)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Su et al., 2015
    76.
    Su, S. ∙ Zhao, Q. ∙ He, C. ...
    miR-142-5p and miR-130a-3p are regulated by IL-4 and IL-13 and control profibrogenic macrophage program
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:8523
    Crossref
    Scopus (191)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    , 2018
    77.
    Su, S. ∙ Chen, J. ∙ Yao, H. ...
    CD10(+)GPR77(+) Cancer-Associated Fibroblasts Promote Cancer Formation and Chemoresistance by Sustaining Cancer Stemness
    Cell. 2018; 172:841-856
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (802)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with slight modifications. Briefly, we incubated specimens in 5% FBS/DMEM containing 2mg/ml collagenase I (Cat# 17100-017, GIBCO), 0.4 mg/ml pronase (Cat# 10165921001, Roche), and 2mg/ml hyaluronidase (Cat# H1136, Sigma-Aldrich) for 4 hr, followed by 11.5% OptiPrep™ (Cat# D1556, Sigma-Aldrich) density gradient centrifugation to purify primary fibroblasts. Fibroblasts were checked for > 90% positive staining for the fibroblast markers α-SMA (Cat# F3777, Sigma-Aldrich) or desmin (Cat# 50-9747-82, eBioscience) and negative staining for the endothelial cell marker CD31 (Cat# 48-0319-42, eBioscience), epithelial marker EpCAM (Cat# 12-9326-42, Invitrogen) or hematopoietic cell marker CD45 (Cat# 11-0451-82, eBioscience) to exclude the contamination of other cell types before subjected to further experiments. We obtained approximately 0.5-2 × 106 fibroblasts per gram from human liver samples and 0.5-1 × 105 fibroblasts per mouse liver. Fibroblasts were cultured in 10% FBS/DMEM medium and passaged every 6–8 days. In some experiments, fibroblasts isolated from patients without NAFLD were treated with 250 μM palmitate (Cat# P9767, Sigma-Aldrich), 1 μM cyclosporine A (CsA) (Cat# S2286, Selleck Chemicals), 5 μM Mito-TEMPO (Cat# ALX-430-150, Enzolife sciences), 5 μM Diphenyleneiodonium chloride (DPI) (Cat# S8639, Selleck Chemicals), or 1 mM N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC) (Cat# 9165, Sigma-Aldrich) for 24 hr before being subjected to further experiments. We used fibroblasts from passages two to nine.

    Animal Studies

    Male C57BL/6J mice (6 weeks old) were obtained from Sun Yat-Sen University Laboratory Animal Center. Mice were maintained in a 12 hr light/dark cycle at 25°C with free access to food and water. After acclimatization for one week, mice were fed with either a control diet (59.4% carbohydrate, 4.3% lipid, and 24.3% protein) or high-fat diets (2% cholesterol, 0.2% cholic acid, 8% yolk powder, 18% lard; 43.0% carbohydrate, 25.9% lipid, and 19.7% protein) (Readydietech, China) for 16 weeks. Mice were then randomly divided into three groups which respectively received an intravenous injection of PBS or mito-NP loaded with empty vectors (5 μg per mouse) or SCAR-overexpressing vectors (5 μg per mouse) every 3 days. After 8 weeks, mice were fasted for 6 hr and sacrificed. Livers and sera were harvested and subjected to further experiments. To evaluate the in vivo toxicity of mito-NP, creatine kinase (CK), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and MB isoenzyme of CK (CK-MB), alanine transaminase (ALT), aspartate transaminase (AST), total bilirubin (T-BIL), direct bilirubin (D-BIL), creatinine (CR), and urea nitrogen (BUN) in serum were detected by Synchron LX 20 analyzer (Beckman Coulter). Body weight was measured once a week. All animal experiments were approved by the Institutional Review Boards and Animal Care and Use Committees of Sun Yat-Sen University.

    Method Details

    Extracellular Acidification and Oxygen Consumption Rate Assays

    The extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) and cellular oxygen consumption rate (OCR) were tested by Seahorse XF Glycolysis Stress Test Kit (Cat# 103020-100, Seahorse Bioscience) and Seahorse XF Cell Mito Stress Test Kit (Cat# 103015-100, Seahorse Bioscience), respectively, in the XF24 Extracellular Flux Analyzer (Seahorse Bioscience) according to the manufacturer’s protocols. Briefly, 1 × 104 fibroblasts per well were seeded into 24-well Seahorse XF24 cell culture plates and cultured with 10% FBS DMEM overnight. Cells were washed and incubated with Seahorse XF Base Medium (Cat# 103193-100, Seahorse Bioscience) supplemented with 2 mM L-glutamine at 37°C for 1 hr in a CO2-free incubator before measurement. After baseline measurements, glucose (10mM), the oxidative phosphorylation inhibitor oligomycin (1 μM), and the glycolytic inhibitor 2-DG (50mM) were sequentially injected into each well at indicated time points to evaluate ECAR; oligomycin (1 μM), the reversible inhibitor of oxidative phosphorylation FCCP (p-trifluoromethoxy carbonyl cyanide phenylhydrazone) (1 μM), and the mitochondrial complex I inhibitor rotenone plus the mitochondrial complex III inhibitor antimycin A (Rote/AA) (0.5 μM) were sequentially injected to evaluate OCR. The reagents were provided in the Test Kits unless stated otherwise. Data were assessed by Seahorse XF-24 Wave software. Three experimental replicates were performed for the fibroblasts isolated from each patient. OCR and ECAR are displayed in pmol/min and mpH/min, respectively.

    Mitochondrial Membrane Potential (ΔΨm) Assay

    Mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) was studied using the JC-1 fluorescence with the Mitochondrial Membrane Potential Assay Kit (Cat# M34152, Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, fibroblasts at a density of 5 × 105 cells/well in a 6-well cell culture plate were incubated with 1 mg/mL JC-1 at 37°C for 20 min and rinsed three times with PBS. Fluorescent signals were analyzed by Zeiss LSM 800 confocal microscopy or CytoFlex flow cytometry (Beckman Coulter). JC-1 monomers (green) fluorescence was observed by excitation at 514nm and examination of the emission at 529 nm. JC-1 aggregates (red) fluorescence was observed by excitation at 585 nm and examination of the emission at 590nm. JC-1 dye exhibits potential-dependent accumulation in mitochondria, which is indicated by a fluorescence emission shift from green (529nm) to red (590nm). Therefore, the results are expressed as a ratio of 590/529 nm fluorescence.

    Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM)

    For transmission electron microscopy (TEM), cells were fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde solution (Cat# G6257, Sigma-Aldrich) (prepared in PBS, 0.2 M and pH 7.4) for 4 hr at 4°C and then post-fixed with 1% osmium tetroxide solution (Cat# 19140, Electron Microscopy Sciences) (prepared in PBS, 0.2 M and pH 7.4) for 1 hr at room temperature. Subsequently, the samples were washed 3 times with 0.1 M PBS (PH7.4) for 15 min each time, dehydrated through a graded series of ethanol to acetone, infiltrated, and embedded in epoxy resin (Cat# 31185, Sigma-Aldrich) that was polymerized in 60°C thermostats for 48 hr. The cell blocks were cut into ultrathin sections (70 nm thick) that were collected on formvar-coated nickel slot grids and stained with 2% uranyl acetate (Cat# 22400, Electron Microscopy Sciences) and 0.4% lead citrate (Cat# 15326, Sigma-Aldrich) for 15 min at room temperature. The ultrathin sections were examined using transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai G2 Spirit BioTWIN).

    Detection of Cytosolic ROS and Mitochondrial ROS

    Cytosolic ROS and mitochondrial ROS were detected by DCFH-DA (Cat# D6883, Sigma-Aldrich) and MitoSOX (Cat# M36008, Invitrogen), respectively. Briefly, fibroblasts at a density of 5 × 105 cells/well in a 6-well cell culture plate were incubated with 10 μM DCFH-DA or 5 μM MitoSOX working solution at 37°C for 20 min in darkness. Cells were washed thrice with PBS and covered with 1 μg/ml Hoechst 33342 (Cat# H3570, Invitrogen). Fluorescent signals were analyzed by Zeiss LSM 800 confocal microscopy or CytoFlex flow cytometry.
    Alternatively, cytosolic ROS and mitochondrial ROS were detected using cytoORP and mitoORP sensors respectively, which genetically encode ratiometric GFP probes to detect compartment-specific ROS. CytoORP and mitoORP sensors were constructed by Synbio Technologies as previously described (Dey et al., 2016
    14.
    Dey, S. ∙ Sidor, A. ∙ O’Rourke, B.
    Compartment-specific Control of Reactive Oxygen Species Scavenging by Antioxidant Pathway Enzymes
    J. Biol. Chem. 2016; 291:11185-11197
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (85)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Fibroblasts were transfected with cytoORP or mitoORP sensors using Lipofectamine 3000 (Cat# L3000015, Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. After 48 hr, mitoORP or cytoORP were excited with the 405 and 488nm laser lines, and emission was detected with a 515nm bandpass filter using Zeiss LSM 800 confocal microscopy. The 405/488 nm excitation ratio was calculated by ImageJ software. The detail information of primers and vectors is listed in Table S3.

    Three-Dimensional Collagen Gels

    Cell suspensions in serum-free media were mixed with 3mg/ml neutralized rat tail collagen type I (Cat# 354249, Corning) at a ratio of 2:1. Then, 500 μL cell suspensions at a density of 1 × 105 cells/ml were seeded onto 24-well culture plates. The gels were allowed to polymerize at 37°C for 1 hr. Thereafter, 1 mL media was added and the edges of the gels were detached from the well walls. After 48 hr, the gel images were taken by Nikon Ni-U microscopy and gel areas were measured using ImageJ software.

    Western Blotting

    Total proteins were extracted from cells using radio-immunoprecipitation assay (RIPA) buffer (Cat# R0278, Sigma-Aldrich) supplemented with protease inhibitor (1:100, Cat# ab65621, Abcam) and phosphatase inhibitor (1:100, Cat# 78442, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Protein concentration was measured by BCA Protein Assay Kit (Cat# 23225, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Equal amounts of protein were separated by electrophoresis on 10% polyacrylamide gels (Cat# PG112, EpiZyme Biotechnology, China), transblotted onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes and incubated with antibodies against α-SMA (1:1000, Cat# ab32575, Abcam), collagen I (1:1000, Cat# ab34710, Abcam), collagen III (1:1000, Cat# ab7778, Abcam), PGC-1α (1:1000, Cat# AB3242, Sigma-Aldrich), CypD (1:1000, Cat# ab231155, Abcam), CHOP (1:1000, Cat# 2895s, Cell Signaling Technology), ATF4 (1:1000, Cat# 10835-1-AP, Proteintech), p-PERK (1:1000, Cat# DF7576, Affinity), p-eIF2α (1:1000, Cat# bs4842R, Bioss), ATP5A (1:1000, Cat# ab176569, Abcam), ATP5B (1:1000, Cat# ab128743, Abcam), HSP60 (1:5000, Cat# ab46798, Abcam), AIF (1:1000, Cat# ab32516, Abcam), Tom20 (1:1000, Cat# ab56783, Abcam), hnRNPA1 (1:1000, Cat# ab5832, Abcam), hnRNPA2B1 (1:1000, Cat# ab6102, Abcam), hnRNPC (1:1000, Cat# ab133607, Abcam), eIF4A3 (1:1000, Cat# ab32485, Abcam), hnRNPF (1:1000, Cat# NBP1-33607, Novus), hnRNPH (1:1000, Cat# ab10374, Abcam), hnRNPM (1:1000, Cat# NB200-314, Novus), hnRNPU (1:1000, Cat# ab10297, Abcam), RNase L (1:1000, Cat# A9840, ABclonal), COX IV (1:1000, Cat# ab16056, Abcam), GFP (1:5000, Cat# ab183734, Abcam), FLAG (1:1000, Cat# F1804, Sigma-Aldrich) or GAPDH (1:2000, Cat# 60004-1-Ig, Proteintech) at 4°C overnight. Afterward, the membranes were incubated with HRP-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG (1:3000, Cat# 7074S, Cell Signaling Technology) or anti-mouse IgG (1:3000, Cat# 7076S, Cell Signaling Technology) secondary antibodies for 1 hr at room temperature. Immunoreactive bands were visualized using SuperSignal™ West Femto (Cat# 34095, Thermo Fisher Scientific) in iBright™ imaging systems or X-ray film. In some experiments, the previous primary antibody and secondary antibody were stripped from the PVDF membrane with stripping buffer (Cat# P0025, Beyotime, Shanghai, China) for 5 min. After being re-blocked, the membrane was re-incubated with another primary antibody at 4°C overnight. The following steps were the same as described above.

    ELISA Assay

    Concentrations of human IL-1β (Cat# E-EL-H0149c, ElabScience), TNF-α (Cat# E-EL-H0109c, ElabScience), IL-8 (Cat# E-EL-H0048c, ElabScience), and CCL-2 (Cat# DCP00, R&D Systems) were detected using ELISA kits according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, cell culture media were collected and centrifuged at 1000 g for 20 min to remove cell debris. 200 μL of supernatants were used in the ELISA assays. Three experimental replicates were performed for the fibroblasts isolated from each patient.

    Apoptosis Analysis

    Cells were dissociated by 0.25% trypsin-EDTA and harvested by centrifugation. Apoptosis was determined using an Annexin V Apoptosis Detection Kit (Cat# BMS500FI/300, Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, cells were incubated with 100 μL of binding buffer containing 5 μL of FITC-conjugated Annexin V antibody for 15 min at room temperature. After incubation, the cells were washed and resuspended in binding buffer (200 μL) containing 5 μL of Propidium Iodide (PI) Staining Solution and analyzed by CytoFlex (Beckman Coulter) flow cytometry immediately. Data were analyzed by FlowJo software (Treestar).

    Expression Profile Analysis of circRNAs

    Total RNAs were extracted using TRIzol reagent. The purity and concentration of total RNAs were determined by NanoDrop ND-1000 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Total RNAs were digested with RNase R (1U/μg, Cat# RNR07250, Epicenter) to enrich circular RNA, amplified, and transcribed into fluorescent cRNA using Arraystar Super RNA Labeling Kit (Cat# 074301, Arraystar) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The labeled cirRNAs were hybridized onto Arraystar Human circRNA Arrays V2 (8 × 15K, Arraystar), and incubated for 17 hr at 65°C in an Agilent Hybridization Oven. Hybridized arrays were washed and scanned with Agilent Scanner G2505C. Data was extracted using Agilent Feature Extraction software. A series of data processing including quantile normalization were performed by R software limma package. The circRNAs that at least 1 out of 2 samples containing flags in “P” or “M” (defined by GeneSpring software) were retained for differential analyses. Differentially expressed circRNAs with statistical significance between two groups were identified by fold change cutoff or through Volcano Plot filtering. The circRNA expression profile data are available in the GEO databases (accession number GSE134146).

    Fractionation Assay of Mitochondria

    Mitochondrial fractionation was performed using Mitochondria Isolation Kit for Cultured Cells (Cat# 89874, Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, 1 × 106 - 1 × 107 fibroblasts were collected and incubated in ice-cold mitochondria isolation buffer for 15 min. After homogenate, nuclei and unbroken cells were discarded after centrifugation at 600 g for 10 min. The pellet enriched in the mitochondrial fraction and supernatant enriched in the cytosolic fraction were obtained after centrifugation at 10,000 g for 10 min. To further isolate mitochondrial outer-membrane and mitoplast (inner-membrane plus matrix), isolated mitochondrial fraction was resuspended in 0.15 mg/mL digitonin (Cat# D141, Sigma-Aldrich) for 15 min. Afterward, mitochondria isolation buffer was added and the suspension was then centrifuged at 12,000 × g for 10 min. Pellets were collected as mitoplasts (Wang et al., 2020
    81.
    Wang, J. ∙ Zhu, P. ∙ Li, R. ...
    Bax inhibitor 1 preserves mitochondrial homeostasis in acute kidney injury through promoting mitochondrial retention of PHB2
    Theranostics. 2020; 10:384-397
    Crossref
    Scopus (110)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    The mitochondria-targeting nanoparticles were prepared using the classic nanoprecipitation method. In brief, the Meo-PEG-b-PDPA polymer was dissolved in DMF (Cat# 227056, Sigma-Aldrich) to form a homogeneous solution with a concentration of 10 mg/mL. Subsequently, a mixture of TACP (5 mg/mL in DMSO) and 10 μg circRNA-expressing vectors (1 mg/mL aqueous solution), 10 μg pLKO.1-puro shRNA construct (1 mg/mL aqueous solution) or 10 μg pXCX-CMV-EGFP (1 mg/mL aqueous solution) was prepared and mixed with 200 μL of Meo-PEG-b-PDPA solution. Under vigorously stirring (1000 rpm), the mixture was added dropwise to 5 mL of deionized water. The formed nanoparticle dispersion was transferred to an ultrafiltration device (MWCO 100 K, EMD Millipore) and centrifuged to remove the organic solvent and free compounds. After washing with ultrapure water thrice, the obtained nanoparticles were dispersed in 1 mL of ultrapure water. The size and zeta potential were determined by DLS (Brookhaven Instruments Corporation).
    To determine the vector encapsulation efficiency (EE%) and biodistribution, 10 μg circRNA expressing vectors were labeled with 0.5 μL of Cy5 using Label IT® Tracker Intracellular Nucleic Acid Localization Kits (Cat# MIR 7021, Mirus) and then encapsulated into the nanoparticles prepared as described above. Subsequently, 5 μL of the nanoparticle solution was mixed with 20-fold DMSO. The standard was prepared by mixing 5 μL of naked Cy5-labeled vectors (1 μg/μL) with 20-fold DMSO. The fluorescence intensity (FI) was measured using a multimode microplate reader (TECAN SPARK 10M), and the vector encapsulation efficiency was calculated as EE% = (FINP/FIStandard) × 100%. Nanoparticles with a vector EE% greater than 80% were adopted for further experiments.
    Fibroblasts were seeded into 24-well plates (5 × 104 cells/well) and cultured in DMEM containing 10% FBS. After 24 hr, the cells were incubated with mito-NP at a vector concentration of 200 ng/mL for 48-72 hr and then subjected to further experiments.

    Mass Spectrometry Analysis

    Mass spectrometric analysis of RNA-binding proteins was performed as we previously described (Chen et al., 2019
    10.
    Chen, F. ∙ Chen, J. ∙ Yang, L. ...
    Extracellular vesicle-packaged HIF-1α-stabilizing lncRNA from tumour-associated macrophages regulates aerobic glycolysis of breast cancer cells

    ). Briefly, proteins pull-downed by SCAR probes and antisense probes were extracted with 50% acetonitrile (Cat# 271004, Sigma-Aldrich) and dried. Dried proteins were incubated with 10mM dithiothreitol (Cat# 43815, Sigma-Aldrich) and 55mM iodoacetamide (Cat# A3221, Sigma-Aldrich) successively, washed with 25mM ammonium bicarbonate (Cat# A6141, Sigma-Aldrich), and dried again. The acquired data were analyzed against the customized protein database using Mascot software (version 2.3.01 Matrix Science, London, UK) against a human RefSeq database, and peak lists were searched against the Homo sapiens Uniprot FASTA database. Data analysis was performed with the Perseus software in the MaxQuant computational platform and in the R statistical computing environment. Data were imputed by creating a Gaussian distribution of random numbers with a s.d. of 30% in comparison to the s.d. of measured values, and one s.d. downshift of the mean to simulate the distribution of low signal values.

Biotinylated proteins were eluted by boiling the beads in 60 μL 1 × protein loading buffer (Cat# NP0007, Invitrogen) supplemented with 20 mM dithiothreitol (Cat# 43815, Sigma-Aldrich) and 2 mM biotin (Cat# 2031, Sigma-Aldrich). The streptavidin eluate (SAE) was collected for subsequent western blotting experiments as described above.
    For RIP assay (Kaewsapsak et al., 2017
    37.
    Kaewsapsak, P. ∙ Shechner, D.M. ∙ Mallard, W. ...
    Live-cell mapping of organelle-associated RNAs via proximity biotinylation combined with protein-RNA crosslinking
    eLife. 2017; 6:e29224
    Crossref
    Scopus (127)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), the cells were crosslinked by addition of 5 mL crosslink-quench solution (0.1% (v/v) formaldehyde (Cat# 252549, Sigma-Aldrich), 10 mM sodium ascorbate, and 5 mM Trolox in PBS). After 1 min, the media were aspirated, and the cells were again incubated in 5 mL fresh crosslink-quench solution for 9 min at room temperature with gentle agitation. The crosslinking reaction was terminated by addition of glycine (Cat# G7126, Sigma-Aldrich) to a final concentration of 125 mM for 5 min at room temperature. Cells were washed twice with PBS, harvested by scraping, and pelleted by centrifugation. The pellets were lysed with Pierce® IP lysis buffer (Cat# 87787, Thermo Fisher Scientific) supplemented with protease-inhibitor cocktail (1:100, Cat# ab65621, Abcam) and 1,000 U/ml RNase inhibitor (Cat# N2511, Promega) for 15 min at 4°C with end-over-end agitation. Lysates were then clarified by centrifugation at 15,000 × g for 5 min at 4°C, transferred to fresh tubes, and each diluted with 500 μL Native lysis buffer (NLB: 25 mM Tris pH 7.4, 150 mM KCl, 0.5% NP-40, 5 mM EDTA) supplemented with 10 mM ascorbate and 5 mM Trolox. 20% of each sample was removed as the ‘input’. The remainder was added to 50 μL streptavidin-coated magnetic bead slurry (Cat# 65305, Invitrogen), which had been equilibrated by two washes in 1:1 IP lysis buffer: NLB. Samples were incubated for 2 hr at 4°C with end-over-end agitation. Beads were subsequently washed with the following series of buffers (1 mL each, 5 min per wash, 4°C, with gentle end-over-end agitation): (1) RIPA buffer, supplemented with trolox and ascorbate, (2) RIPA buffer without radi- cal quenchers, (3) high salt buffer (1 M KCl, 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 5 mM EDTA), (4) urea buffer (2 M Urea, 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 5 mM EDTA), (5) RIPA Buffer, (6) 1:1 RIPA: NLB, (7) NLB, and (8) TE (10 mM Tris, pH 7.4, 1 mM EDTA). Enriched RNAs were released from the beads by proteolysis in 100 μL of Elution Buffer (2% N-lauryl sarcoside, 10 mM EDTA, 5 mM DTT, 200 mg proteinase K (Cat# AM2548, Invitrogen) and 4 U RNase inhibitor in PBS) at 42°C for 1 hr and at 55°C for another 1 hr. Eluted samples were cleaned up using GeneJET RNA Purification Kit (Cat# K0731, Thermo Fisher Scientific) following the manufacturer’s protocol and eluted into 50 μL H2O. Then, contaminating DNA was removed by digestion with 5 U RQ1 RNase-free DNase I (Cat# 89836, Thermo Fisher Scientific) in 100 μL manufacturer’s supplied buffer at 37°C for 30 min. Purified RNAs were again cleaned up using GeneJET RNA Purification Kit and eluted into 30 μL H2O before being subjected to PCR experiments as described above.

    Assessment of mPTP Opening by Calcein Loading/CoCl2 Quenching

    We performed calcein-AM loading/CoCl2 quenching assay to evaluate mPTP opening as previously described (Ying et al., 2018
    88.
    Ying, Z. ∙ Xiang, G. ∙ Zheng, L. ...
    Short-Term Mitochondrial Permeability Transition Pore Opening Modulates Histone Lysine Methylation at the Early Phase of Somatic Cell Reprogramming
    Cell Metab. 2018; 28:935-945
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (34)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) using Transition Pore Assay Kit (Cat# I35103, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Briefly, fibroblasts were treated with 1 μM calcein-AM in darkness at 37°C for 15 min in the presence of 5 mM cobalt chloride (CoCl2) to quench the cytoplasmic and nuclear signals. Calcein was excited at 494nm, and emission was recorded at 517 nm. Cells were washed twice with Hanks’ balanced salt solution-10 mM HEPES (pH 7.2) before being evaluated by Zeiss LSM 800 confocal microscope or CytoFlex flow cytometry.

    Co-Immunoprecipitation

    Immunoprecipitation (IP) of ATP synthase, ATP5A, or ATP5B was performed using mouse anti-human ATP synthase Immunocapture antibody (1:100, Cat# ab109867, Abcam), mouse anti-human ATP5A antibody (1:100, Cat# ab14748, Abcam), or mouse anti-human ATP5B antibody (1:100, Cat# ab14730, Abcam) at 4°C overnight, followed by incubation with protein A/G magnetic beads (Cat# 88802, Thermo Fisher Scientific) and washed with lysis buffer. Mouse IgG (1:100, Cat# 12-371, Millipore) was used as a negative control. The co-immunoprecipitated proteins were resuspended in 1 × SDS sample buffer, heated at 95 - 100°C for 5 min, and then detected by western blotting using rabbit anti-human CypD (1:1000, Cat# ab231155, Abcam), rabbit anti-human ATP5A (1:1000, Cat# ab176569, Abcam), or rabbit anti-human ATP5B (1:1000, Cat# ab128743, Abcam).

    shRNA and siRNA Mediated Silencing

    For shRNA transduction, a lentiviral vector plasmid pLKO.1-puro (GenePharma Inc, Shanghai, China) was used to construct the stable clones. To produce lentiviral particles, 5 × 106 HEK293FT cells in a 10-cm dish were transfected with 10 μg of pLKO.1-puro shRNA construct. The supernatant containing viral particles was harvested twice at 48 hr and 72 hr after transfection and filtered through 0.22 μm Millex-GP Filter Unit (Millipore). Virus carrying shRNAs were used to transduce primary human fibroblasts as we previously described with slight modifications (Su et al., 2015
    76.
    Su, S. ∙ Zhao, Q. ∙ He, C. ...
    miR-142-5p and miR-130a-3p are regulated by IL-4 and IL-13 and control profibrogenic macrophage program
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:8523
    Crossref
    Scopus (191)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Briefly, 5 × 105 cells in 6-well plates were transduced with the lentiviral vectors (multiplicity of infection [MOI] of 30) and 10 μg/mL polybrene (Cat# H9268, Sigma-Aldrich) at 37°C overnight. The medium was then aspirated and replaced with fresh growth medium. For siRNA transfection, 5 × 105 fibroblasts were plated in 6-well plates and transfected with specific siRNA duplexes using Lipofectamine 3000 (Cat# L3000015, Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. After three days, the cells were harvested for further analyses. To activate RNase L, fibroblasts were transfected with poly(I:C) (1 μg/mL, Cat# P9582, Sigma-Aldrich) using Lipofectamine 3000 (Cat# L3000015, Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The knockdown efficiency of RNA and proteins was evaluated by qRT-PCR and western blotting, respectively. The oligonucleotide sequences of shRNA and siRNA are listed in Table S3.

    31.
    Herai, R.H. ∙ Negraes, P.D. ∙ Muotri, A.R.
    Evidence of nuclei-encoded spliceosome mediating splicing of mitochondrial RNA

    ), using minimum-length 18, error-rate 0.2, overlap five options. These datasets were gapped-aligned against human (build hg19) genomes and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) with the STAR software package (Dobin et al., 2013

    Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

    ChIP assay was performed using ChIP Assay Kit (Cat# 26157, Thermo Fisher Scientific) as we previously described (Huang et al., 2018
    33.
    Huang, D. ∙ Chen, J. ∙ Yang, L. ...
    NKILA lncRNA promotes tumor immune evasion by sensitizing T cells to activation-induced cell death
    Nat. Immunol. 2018; 19:1112-1125
    Crossref
    Scopus (304)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Su et al., 2015
    76.
    Su, S. ∙ Zhao, Q. ∙ He, C. ...
    miR-142-5p and miR-130a-3p are regulated by IL-4 and IL-13 and control profibrogenic macrophage program
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:8523

    ). Briefly, fibroblasts were fixed in 1% formaldehyde for 30 min at room temperature. Fixed cells were harvested, lysed, and sonicated for 10 cycles of 30 s on/45 s off. The lysates were incubated with antibodies directly against PGC-1α (1:100, Cat# AB3242, Sigma) or control rabbit IgG (1:100, Cat# 2729, Cell Signaling Technology) at 4°C overnight. PGC-1α was then immunoprecipitated by protein A/G magnetic beads (Cat# 88802, Thermo Fisher Scientific) and washed with lysis buffer. DNA was extracted by proteinase K-chloroform method and subjected to PCR amplification. The primer sequences used in ChIP assay are described in Table S3.

    Biodistribution of mito-NP in vivo

    To investigate the organ distribution of mito-NP in vivo, circRNA-expressing vectors were labeled with Cy5 using Label IT® Tracker Intracellular Nucleic Acid Localization Kits (Cat# MIR 7021, Mirus) as decribed above. Healthy male C57BL/6J mice (10 weeks old) were randomly given an intravenous injection with naked Cy5-labeled vectors (0.2 mg/kg), mito-NP loaded with Cy5-labeled vectors (0.2 mg/kg) or PBS via the tail vein. The mice were sacrificed 24 hr after the injection. The main organs were harvested and then imaged using the Maestro 2 In-Vivo Imaging System (Cri Inc.). To quantify the accumulation of vectors in organs, the fluorescence intensity of each tissue was quantified by ImageJ software as we previously described (Xu et al., 2017
    87.
    Xu, X. ∙ Wu, J. ∙ Liu, Y. ...
    Multifunctional Envelope-Type siRNA Delivery Nanoparticle Platform for Prostate Cancer Therapy
    ACS Nano. 2017; 11:2618-2627
    Crossref
    Scopus (175)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To evaluate the vector uptake by fibroblasts, liver fibroblasts were isolated from mouse livers as described above. The fluorescence intensity of isolated fibroblasts was examined by CytoFlex flow cytometry. To quantify the sub-cellular distribution of vectors in fibroblasts of mouse livers, the mitochondrial and cytosolic fractions were isolated as described above and homogenized in lysis buffer. The lysates were transferred to a black 96-well plate (Corning). The fluorescence intensity of the samples was measured by a multimode microplate reader (TECAN SPARK 10M) with an excitation at 649 nm and emission at 670 nm. The concentration of Cy5-labeled vectors in each sample was calculated from a standard curve. A standard curve was generated by series dilution of mito-NP loaded with Cy5-labeled vectors.

    Glucose Tolerance Tests (GTT) and Insulin Tolerance Tests (ITT)

    Glucose-tolerance tests were performed in mice after an overnight fast. Glucose was injected intraperitoneally (2g/kg body weight). Blood glucose concentrations in blood were measured at the indicated times with a glucometer (Roche). Insulin tolerance tests were performed in mice fed ad libitum. After determination of basal blood glucose concentrations, each mouse received an intraperitoneal injection of insulin (1 IU/kg body weight; Cat# 11070-73-8, Sigma-Aldrich). Glucose concentrations in blood were measured at the indicated times.

    Histopathology

    Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded liver biopsies or sections were cut into 4 μm serial sections. NAFLD severity was detected by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining and quantitated by the steatosis activity and fibrosis (SAF) score (Bedossa and FLIP Pathology Consortium, 2014
    4.
    Bedossa, P., FLIP Pathology Consortium
    Utility and appropriateness of the fatty liver inhibition of progression (FLIP) algorithm and steatosis, activity, and fibrosis (SAF) score in the evaluation of biopsies of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
    Hepatology. 2014; 60:565-575
    Crossref
    Scopus (489)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Sirius red staining was performed by Picro Sirius Red Stain Kit (Cat# ab150681, Abcam). For immunohistochemistry, sections were deparaffinized with xylene and rehydrated. Antigen retrieval was performed by heating in 10 mM sodium citrate (pH 6.0). Slides were incubated in 3% hydrogen peroxide/methanol for 10 min and washed with PBS. After blocking with normal goat serum (Cat# ab7481, Abcam), sections were incubated overnight with rabbit anti-mouse collagen III (1:100, Cat# ab7778, Abcam), followed by incubation with HRP-conjugated anti-rabbit secondary antibodies (1:300, Cat# 7074S, Cell Signaling Technology) for 1 hr at room temperature. Diaminobenzidine (Cat# 34002, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used as a chromogen, and sections were lightly counterstained with hematoxylin. For immunofluorescent staining, deparaffinized and rehydrated slides were incubated with rabbit anti-mouse F4/80 monoclonal antibody (1:100, Cat# 30325, Cell Signaling Technology) or rabbit anti-human α-SMA monoclonal antibody (1:100, Cat# ab32575, Abcam) overnight at 4°C. Thereafter, slides were washed thrice with PBST, incubated with DyLight 488 goat anti-rabbit IgG (1:300, Cat# E032220-01, EarthOx) for 1 hr at room temperature and stained with Hoechst 33342 (Cat# H3570, Invitrogen). For ROS detection, sections were stained with 1 μM Dihydroethidium (DHE, Cat# D11347, Invitrogen) in darkness at 37°C for 30 min before goat serum blockade. Morphometric analysis was performed using Nikon Ni-U microscopy. An algorithm learning tool was performed by Imaris 9.0 to evaluate the colocalization of α-SMA and DHE signals as described in the FISH and Immunofluorescence Analysis section above. Quantification was performed by morphometric analysis in randomly chosen sections (400 × magnification, 10 fields/sample).

    Liver Stiffness Measurement by Transient Elastography

    Transient elastography was performed using a FibroScan system (Echosens, Paris, France) by the M probe as we and others previously described (Friedrich-Rust et al., 2016
    21.
    Friedrich-Rust, M. ∙ Poynard, T. ∙ Castera, L.
    Critical comparison of elastography methods to assess chronic liver disease
    Nat. Rev. Gastroenterol. Hepatol. 2016; 13:402-411
    Crossref
    Scopus (187)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhang et al., 2019
    91.
    Zhang, G.L. ∙ Zhao, Q.Y. ∙ Lin, C.S. ...
    Transient Elastography and Ultrasonography: Optimal Evaluation of Liver Fibrosis and Cirrhosis in Patients with Chronic Hepatitis B Concurrent with Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
    BioMed Res. Int. 2019; 2019:3951574
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). After an overnight fast, patients underwent transient elastography examination within 3 days of liver biopsy by trained operators who had previously performed at least 500 scans in patients with chronic liver disease. The operators were blinded to the clinical data and pathology results. The value expressed in kilopascal (kPa) was recorded as a representation of liver stiffness. Up to 10 valid measurements were performed for each patient. A success rate above 60% and an interquartile range/median ratio of less than 30% were considered reliable.

    Determination of Homeostasis Model Assessment-Insulin Resistance (HOMA-IR)

    The homeostasis model assessment method was used to calculate insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), as described by others (Rosso et al., 2019
    69.
    Rosso, C. ∙ Kazankov, K. ∙ Younes, R. ...
    Crosstalk between adipose tissue insulin resistance and liver macrophages in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
    J. Hepatol. 2019; 71:1012-1021
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (124)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) from fasting plasma glucose and insulin concentrations using the following formula: fasting plasma glucose (mmol/L) × fasting plasma insulin (mU/L) / 22.5.

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    The information about statistical details and methods is indicated in the figure legends, text, or methods. Data are presented as either mean or median and analyzed for comparison of two groups by Student’s t test or Mann-Whitney U test, respectively. All data were analyzed using two tailed tests unless otherwise specified, and a p value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Correlation analysis was evaluated using Pearson correlation and regression analysis. Flow cytometry data was analyzed using FlowJo software. The measurements of all statistical values were performed using GraphPad Prism 7.0 or SPSS 23.0, unless otherwise described in the figure legends or methods. Error bars in the experiments indicate the standard error of the mean (SEM) as mentioned in the figure legends for a minimum of three independent experiments unless otherwise indicated.

    Cookie Preference Center

    We use cookies which are necessary to make our site work. We may also use additional cookies to analyse, improve and personalise our content and your digital experience. For more information, see our Cookie Policy and the list of Google Ad-Tech Vendors.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
